snippet: The rule changes, which were intended to hasten the nominating process, have failed to narrow a sprawling field while potentially aiding Donald J. Trump’s chances.
abstract: Rules put in place by Republican party following 2012 presidential election, aimed at avoiding long and contentious nomination process, could backfire, thwarted by sprawling candidate field and frustrated base; candidate is not likely to emerge until late spring; some changes may benefit candidacy of Donald Trump, outcome many establishment Republicans hope to avoid.

byline.original: By ADAM NAGOURNEY and JONATHAN MARTIN

lead_paragraph: The rule changes, which were intended to hasten the nominating process, have failed to narrow a sprawling field while potentially aiding Donald J. Trump’s chances.

headline.main: Party Rules to Streamline Race May Backfire for G.O.P.
headline.print_headline: New G.O.P. Rules to Pick Nominee Could Backfire
